subject: Re: [junit] In what order are the test run through...
msgSnippet: ... I have a test suite which needs to talk to a remote process. Here s a class which pre-loads some user data into that remote process using shell scripts:
messageBody:
On Thu, 19 Apr 2001, Christian van der Leeden wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I'm testing some classes which leave state in the db. This one is
> a user class. So I definitely want to have the test to create the
> user before the test to search for the user. AND I'd prefer
> to set this up with new TestSuite(User.class) instead of
> adding the methods by hand.
>
> Is there a specific ordering of the test runs (or method calls)?
> Is the solution to add the test cases by hand?
> suite.addTest("testAddUser");
> suite.addTest("findUser");

I have a test suite which needs to talk to a remote process.
Here's a class which pre-loads some user data into that remote process
using shell scripts:

MPSetup.java:

package com.aravox.nsapi;
public class MPSetup extends TestSetup {
String ip = "10.77.77.77";

public MPSetup( Test t) {
super(t);
}
protected void setUp() {
System.out.println();
System.out.println("com.aravox.nsapi.MPSetup.setUp()");
try {
Runtime.getRuntime().exec("/home/joi/jbproject/TestNSApi/setupTestUsers");
} catch (IOException ioex) {
ioex.printStackTrace();
}
}
protected void tearDown() {
System.out.println();
System.out.println("com.aravox.nsapi.MPSetup.tearDown()");
try {
Runtime.getRuntime().exec("/home/joi/jbproject/TestNSApi/removeTestUsers");
} catch (IOException ioex) {
ioex.printStackTrace();
}
}
protected void setIpAddress( String ip ) {
this.ip = ip;
}
}

Here's how MPSetup is used:

AllTests.java:

package com.aravox.nsapi;
public class AllTests {
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(TestUdpConnect.suite());
...
suite.addTest(TestResBundle.suite());
MPSetup mps = new MPSetup( suite );
mps.setIpAddress( targetFirewall.getIpAddressString() );
return mps;
}
...
}

Note how the AllTests.suite() method builds its own suite, and then
wraps that within an MPSetup object. The resulting mps object is
returned to JUnit.
